questions.question: What is meant by the term sociology?

options.A: Study of developments in the society
options.B: Study of formation of social organisations and government
options.C: Study of human relationships and behavior
options.D: Study of social and cultural history of man

questions.question: Which of the following social sciences does not deal directly with human behavior?
questions.explanation: Political science refers to the study of the judicial systems and institutions that constitute thegovernment. It does not deal directly with human behavior.Anthropology is the study of the physical, social, and cultural history of man. Social anthropologyis extensively used in preventive and social medicine.Social psychology is aimed at understanding the basis of perception, thoughts, ideas, etc., amongpeople in a society or group.Sociology is the study of human relationships and human behavior.

questions.question: Which of the following refers to a system of social relationships between individuals?
questions.explanation: Society is the system of social relationships between people in an area.A community is a social group determined by geographical boundaries and/or common values andinterests.A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof andeating from a common kitchen.Social Institutions are organized complex patterns of behavior in which a number of peopleengage to further a common interest.

questions.question: Which of the following options is correctly matched?

options.A: Social institution- the pattern of inter-relations between persons in a society
options.B: Socialism- organised complex patterns of behaviour in people with a common interest
options.C: Social structure- system of governance based on social ownership
options.D: Socialization- the process by which a person imbibes the social beliefs and customes

questions.explanation: Socialization is the process by which a person in a society imbibes its beliefs, customs, etc.through daily interaction with its members.Social institutions are organized complex patterns of behaviour in which a number of peopleengage to further a common interest. Examples are families, schools, hospitals, etc.Socialism is a system of governance in which production and distribution is based on socialownership (and not private ownership). It is aimed at improving the living standard.Social structure is the pattern of inter-relations between persons in a society.

questions.question: Which of the following terms is used to describe the preventive, therapeutic, andrehabilitative services for the protection of society from antisocial, criminal, or deviantconduct of man?
questions.explanation: Preventive, therapeutic and rehabilitative services for the protection of society from antisocial,criminal or deviant conduct of man is known as social defence.This is in the form of acts, laws and judicial instructions for elements like juvenile delinquency,begging, prison reforms, gambling, etc.509

questions.question: Match the following.
questions.explanation: Culture is the socially acquired learned behaviour. It is passed onto generations through formaland informal learning. It is the representation of customs, beliefs, laws, arts, and moral values of asociety. Cultural factors have a large part to play in health.Customs are the traditionally accepted ways of behaving that is specific to a society. They can befolkways, which are referred to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of humanconduct. Mores are stringent customs followed by a society.Standard of living refers to the scale of the expenditure of a society, the goods they consume andthe services they enjoy.Role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

questions.question: Which of the following does not bring about acculturation?
questions.explanation: Acculturation is the process by which there is the diffusion of cultures between two culturallydifferent groups of people. Acculturation does not take place by folklore. Folklore is the passage ofcustoms and beliefs of a community through generations, merely by word of mouth.Acculturation can happen in the following ways:• Trade and commerce• Industrialization•Religious propagation• Education• ConquestThis phenomenon is also known as culture contact.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct ascending order of the Maslow's hierarchy of needs?
questions.explanation: Maslow's hierarchy of needs was suggested by psychologist Abraham Maslow. It is a motivationaltheory in psychology where human needs are arranged according to hierarchy in a five-levelpyramid.He suggested that the higher needs can be fulfilled only once the lower needs are fulfilled.The ascending order of the needs is shown in the image below.510Maslow's hierarchy of needsMASelf-actualization:achieving one'sfull potential, includingcreative activitiesEsteem needs:prestige & feeling ofaccomplishmentBelongingness & love needs:intimate relationships, friendsSafety needs:security, safetyPhysiological needs:food, water, warmth, restWOMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following could be classified as an ego-integrative need of man?
questions.explanation: Ego-integrative needs of man include power, prestige and self-respect.The needs of man are as follows:•Biological needs- water, food, warmth, medicines, etc.• Social needs- love and affection, fellowship, education, etc.• Economic needs- money and security•Ego-integrative needs- power, prestige and self-respect.

questions.question: What is the benefit that comes from solving one's own problems termed?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic incentives are the benefits that come from solving one's own problems.Incentives are entities that motivate or encourage a specific behaviour. They are generally positivemotivators. The various types of incentives are:•• Intrinsic incentives are the benefits that come from solving one's own problems.• Extrinsic incentives are rewards that do not relate directly to the goal of the desired behaviourlike financial compensation for sterilization.•• Psychological incentives include satisfaction, increased self-esteem, etc.Material incentives include goods or services or financial compensation.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about attitudes in human behaviour?

options.A: It is acquired from social interactions
options.B: It includes an affective or feeling element
options.C: It pre-disposes one to respond in a preferential manner
options.D: It is a temporary and fleeting aspect of human behaviour

questions.explanation: 511Attitude is usually a permanent aspect of a human's behaviour and is difficult to change.It is the enduring organization of beliefs around something that pre-disposes one to respond in apreferential manner. It is usually acquired through social interactions.Attitude includes three components:••A cognitive or knowledge element• An affective or feeling element.• A tendency to act

questions.question: Which of the following terms represent the temporary and provisional views held by people ata point of dispute?
questions.explanation: Opinions are temporary and provisional views held by people at a point of dispute.Beliefs are permanent and stable inner subjective thoughts of a person towards things that arewithout proof. These are usually acquired from family and other close contacts.

questions.question: A 6-yr-old boy is brought to the clinical psychologist for evaluation of intellectual disability.Which formula will she use to calculate the IQ of the child?-
questions.explanation: The intelligence quotient is a score that is obtained from several standardized tests to assesshuman intelligence.Intelligence quotient (IQ) = Mental age x 100 / Chronological age

questions.question: Evaluation for mental retardation was done for a Down syndrome patient. His IQ was foundto be 56. According to Levine and Mark's classification, you would classify him as?
questions.explanation: According to the Levine and Mark's classification, a moron would have an IQ of 50-74.

questions.question: A clinical psychologist was asked to ascertain the IQ of a patient. She categorized the patientas having mild mental retardation. Which of the following represent's the patient's IQ range?
questions.explanation: Mild mental retardation based on IQ score would fall in the range of 50-70.

questions.question: According to Wechsler's scale, which of the following persons would be categorized to haveaverage intelligence?

options.C: A banker with an IQ of 95
options.D: An alcoholic man with an IQ of 85

questions.explanation: According to the Wechsler's Scale, average intelligence would fall in the range of 91–110.

questions.question: Which of the following is an important epidemiological tool to assess disability in children?506

options.B: Wing's Comprehensive Handicaps, Behaviour and Skills Schedule

questions.explanation: Wing's Comprehensive Handicaps, Behaviour and Skills Schedule (HBS) has been used inepidemiological studies to assess the total child population in terms of detailed scales of specificabilities and disabilities.HBS is not useful for children with mental retardation.513
